turns.content: can you create me a white belt to blue belt BJJ training/learning program that i can do at home on a dummy to learn the positions and options from each position etc. I would like to focus on one position a week. the program can span 6 months

Sure, here is a possible training program you can use to go from white belt to blue belt in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ) over the course of six months:

1. Week 1: Guard position
* Start by learning the basic guard position, where you are on your back with your legs wrapped around your opponent's waist.
* Practice transitioning from the guard to other positions, such as the closed guard, open guard, and butterfly guard.
* Work on mastering the fundamental guard techniques, such as the hip escape, bridge, and sweep.
2. Week 2: Closed guard
* Focus on improving your closed guard, where you have your opponent's arms controlled and your legs locked around their body.
* Practice breaking your opponent's posture and attacking with submissions, such as the triangle choke and armbar.
* Work on defending against common closed guard passes, such as the stack pass and leg drag pass.
3. Week 3: Open guard
* Spend this week focusing on the open guard, where your legs are not locked around your opponent's body.
* Practice using the open guard to sweep your opponent and take the top position.
* Work on attacking from the open guard with submissions, such as the omoplata and arm triangle.
4. Week 4: Butterfly guard
* In this week, focus on mastering the butterfly guard, where you have a hook on your opponent's leg with your feet.
* Practice using the butterfly guard to sweep your opponent and take the top position.
* Work on attacking from the butterfly guard with submissions, such as the armbar and guillotine choke.
5. Week 5: Half guard
* Spend this week learning and improving your half guard, where you have one leg trapped between your opponent's legs.
* Practice using the half guard to sweep your opponent and take the top position.
* Work on attacking from the half guard with submissions, such as the Kimura and Americana.
6. Week 6: Side control
* In the final week of this program, focus on mastering the side control position, where you are on top of your opponent with your body perpendicular to theirs.
* Practice using side control to maintain the position and prevent your opponent from escaping.
* Work on attacking from side control with submissions, such as the arm triangle and kimura.

Remember to always warm up before training, and to train with a partner if possible. It's also important to listen to your body and take regular breaks to avoid injury. Most importantly, have fun and enjoy the journey of learning BJJ!
please give me 10 more weeks continuing on from the above program

Here are ten more weeks of training that you can follow to continue your journey from white belt to blue belt in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ):

7. Week 7: Mount position
* In this week, focus on mastering the mount position, where you are on top of your opponent with your body aligned over theirs.
* Practice using the mount to maintain the position and prevent your opponent from escaping.
* Work on attacking from the mount with submissions, such as the arm triangle and armbar.
8. Week 8: Back control
* Spend this week learning and improving your back control, where you have both hooks in and your body aligned behind your opponent's.
* Practice using the back control to maintain the position and prevent your opponent from escaping.
* Work on attacking from the back control with submissions, such as the rear-naked choke and bow and arrow choke.
9. Week 9: Takedowns
* In this week, focus on mastering the fundamentals of takedowns in BJJ.
* Practice executing common takedowns, such as the single leg takedown and double leg takedown.
* Work on defending against takedowns and returning to the guard position.
10. Week 10: Passes
* Spend this week focusing on improving your passing game in BJJ.
* Practice executing common guard passes, such as the knee slice pass and the over-under pass.
* Work on defending against guard passes and returning to the guard position.
11. Week 11: Submissions
* In this week, focus on mastering a variety of submissions in BJJ.
* Practice executing common submissions, such as the armbar, triangle choke, and kimura.
* Work on improving your defense against submissions and escaping from bad positions.
12. Week 12: Transitions
* Spend this week focusing on improving your ability to smoothly transition between different positions in BJJ.
* Practice transitioning from the guard to the mount, back control, and other dominant positions.
* Work on defending against transitions and returning to the guard position.
13. Week 13: Drilling
* In this week, focus on drilling the techniques and movements you have learned in BJJ.
* Practice executing the techniques in a repetitive and controlled manner to improve muscle memory and efficiency.
* Work on integrating the techniques into live sparring and rolling with a partner.
14. Week 14: Sparring
* Spend this week focusing on live sparring and rolling with a partner in BJJ.
* Practice executing the techniques you have learned against a resisting opponent.
* Work on maintaining a good pace and using strategy to outmaneuver your opponent.
15. Week 15: Conditioning
* In this final week, focus on improving your overall physical conditioning for BJJ.
* Practice a variety of exercises, such as push-ups, burpees, and jumping jacks, to improve your strength, endurance, and agility.
* Work on maintaining a healthy diet and getting sufficient rest to support your training.

Remember to always warm up before training, and to listen to your body and take regular breaks to avoid injury. Also, be sure to continue learning and improving your skills and techniques in BJJ, and enjoy the journey of growth and self-improvement.
can you create 4 weeks based around submissions, grips to use in the gi and others such as kimura.

Sure, here is a four-week training program that focuses on submissions, grips, and the kimura in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ):

1. Week 1: Fundamentals of submissions
* In this week, focus on learning the basics of submissions in BJJ.
* Practice executing common submissions, such as the armbar, triangle choke, and omoplata.
* Work on improving your understanding of the mechanics and principles of submissions.
2. Week 2: Gi grips and control
* Spend this week focusing on improving your grip and control game in BJJ.
* Practice executing common grips, such as the lapel grip, sleeve grip, and collar-and-sleeve grip.
* Work on using the grips to control your opponent and set up submissions.
3. Week 3: Kimura attacks and defenses
* In this week, focus on mastering the kimura in BJJ.
* Practice executing the kimura from a variety of positions, such as the guard, side control, and back control.
* Work on improving your defense against the kimura and escaping from bad positions.
4. Week 4: Sparring and drilling
* Spend this week focusing on integrating the techniques you have learned into live sparring and drilling in BJJ.
* Practice executing the techniques against a resisting opponent in sparring.
* Work on drilling the techniques in a repetitive and controlled manner to improve muscle memory and efficiency.

Remember to always warm up before training, and to train with a partner if possible. It's also important to listen to your body and take regular breaks to avoid injury. Most importantly, have fun and enjoy the journey of learning BJJ!
